docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Note: This space is dedicated to documenting the operations of the Automated Mineralogy Lab (AML), covering everything from sample preparation to data processing. This initiative is part of our comprehensive data acquisition protocols; check out the WIIP. Please note that the content is currently being prepared offline and will be available as soon as it is completed. Until the documentation is fully completed, you can learn more about the applications of automated mineralogy from the Publications, and Theses and Dissertations.

🎧 Listen to the GeoPodcast on Automated Mineralogy! 🌍

For more information, please contact aml@kfupm.edu.sa.

docs.title: Introduction
docs.text: Carbon coating is a process used to enhance the conductivity and durability of materials. This guide provides step-by-step instructions for applying a carbon coating effectively.

docs.title: Materials Needed
docs.text:
• Carbon source (e.g., carbon black, graphite)
  • Coating solution (e.g., polymer binder)
  • Spray or dip coating equipment
  • Protective gear (gloves, mask, goggles)

docs.title: Safety Precautions
docs.text:
1. Work in a well-ventilated area.
  2. Wear appropriate personal protective equipment (PPE).
  3. Avoid inhaling fumes or dust from carbon materials.

docs.title: 1. Prepare the Substrate
docs.text:
• Clean the surface of the substrate to remove any contaminants.
  • Dry the substrate completely.

docs.title: 2. Prepare the Coating Solution
docs.text:
• Mix the carbon source with the polymer binder in a clean container.
  • Ensure the mixture is homogeneous.

docs.title: 3. Apply the Coating
docs.text:
• Spray Method:
  • Load the coating solution into the spray equipment.

  • Apply an even coat to the substrate from a distance of about 6-12 inches.

  • Dip Method:

  • Immerse the substrate into the coating solution.
  • Allow it to soak for a few seconds, then remove and let excess solution drip off.

docs.title: 4. Cure the Coating
docs.text:
• Place the coated substrate in an oven at the recommended temperature for curing.
